items.title: Vigorous and Weird
items.summary: You know what's weird? Besides me. That kind of dancing professionals…
items.content_html:
You know what's weird?

Besides me.

That kind of dancing professionals do that kind of feels a little too aggressive.

Like you see them do it and instinctively get into a fighter's stance.

Kinda like rap battles but they're dissing you with their moves instead of their verses.

It's a little too in your face.Â 

Should you be angry whilst dancing?

Angry dancing is amusing.

From mosh pits to breakers.

Another thing that's weird is that war chant thing that those lovely folks from the islands do before rugby games and city council meetings.

I mean, I get it for a sports warmup, but doing it before discussing ordinance 583-31 (item to change water sprinkler services) seems a bit, oh what's the word, ridiculous.

[Dances aggressively. Slows. Then explodes again.]

Oh snap.

[Hakas violently, hands and feet doing things, eyes bulge and widen.]

Ok, ok.

I can see some merit it in this.

[Continues for far longer than necessary, extinguishing any remaining wonder or awe in it.]

I'm ready to go to war.

Next item on the agenda, proposal to paint fire trucks blue instead of red to give fire more fear.

Mother effers, I'm ready.

Â

items.title: Warship
items.summary: Welp, almost forgot to write again today. I starting writing a…
items.content_html:
Welp, almost forgot to write again today.

I starting writing a bit about worship, how we worship the wrong things, but I remembered that part of this whole thing is to realize how sacred life is.

So I erased my rant.

Instead, I would just like to say:

We all worship something.

We bow to it. Pray to it. And believe in it.

Whether it be God or money or a political party or a damn Harley.

We all have faith in something.

I know where I stand.

I know where I fall.

What do you worship?

Because we all worship something.

And how's that working out for you?

If you said, "Great!" Well, keep it up, then.

But if you said something less than positive, I wonder what it could be?

I think how you answer the worship question is about as important as who you choose to live your life with.

It's almost the same answer.

There's an old self-development trope that you are the average of the five people you spend the most time with, but I think it's really just one.

You.

Take you at your highest, take you at your lowest, and everything in between.

That's you.

You are the average of you.

You spend the most time with yourself.

If that bores you, well, you're boring.

If that excites you, well, you're crazy.

And if part of this whole deal is that everything is sacred, well what does that also imply?

You are a part of everything.

Which makes you...

ðŸ˜‡

items.title: AC Phone Home
items.summary: I can't lock in lately. Writing wise. I will say I…
items.content_html:
I can't lock in lately.

Writing wise.

I will say I enjoy the tactile experience of hitting keys again.

Typing.

Clicking.

Clacking.

It's not the same on touch screens.

Even with the haptic stuff, it's just not the same.

Real beats faux real.

Sometimes.

I grew up professionally using Blackberry devices. Although I started with a Treo (so good).

As a bit of a tech guy, I just loved these little pocket computers.

I hung onto the Blackberry line all the way to Passport, when it was clearly on the way down and out because some fruit company starting making phones.

I was loyal to the tactile. The ability to write angry or at least, emotional, emails (I don't do that anymore - the former, I mean, well maybe both).

Pro Tip: Brevity.Â Stoic. No emotion. I should follow my own advice.

The feedback.

There is a bit of a comeback with these types of devices. And you know I always love a comeback.

Phones with keyboards. Physical keyboards in a digital world.

And it's not just us old(ish) folk, either.Â 

It's them damn kids, man.

Some of them want to simplify.Â 

Narrow down their choices.

They want less, and they will pay for it.

Some people are learning that you do not need a four-figure handheld device to make phone calls, take pictures, text and write emails.

And you certainly shouldn't pay for the privilege on a loan.

But I'm just an old(ish) guy. Remembering when they gave you this stuff for free, just for locking in on a contract with the service provider.

And I miss the pitter patter of little keys.

items.title: Storm Before The Quiet
items.summary: ...And we're off! Man, the year is starting off with a…
items.content_html:
...And we're off!

Man, the year is starting off with a bang, ain't it?

A rare Monday where a lot of folks are excited.

Time to shake the fog of holiday serenity/chaos and jump back into your vocational one.

How many people have vocational serenity?

Ooof.

I don't think many.

I won't lecture you today on how important that is.

You likely are busy.

Chaotic.

Right now.

You know what's interesting?Â 

Some people cannot live in serenity.Â 

They generate their own chaos if none is provided to them.

I see this in children and elders.

And everything in between.

I think some are bored, and some, oddly, find a strange comfort in chaos.

Familiarity.

Home.

As an old(ish) curmudgeon, I dig quiet.

Silence!

But even I admit empty house quiet is too quiet. I can hear my ears ring.

It's one of the tradeoffs of being here, the ringing that is.

I'll take it.

I don't even hear it most of the time.

Only when it's too quiet.

And only sometimes.

Ringing in the new year by the ringing in my old ear.

I'm not complaining though.Â 

I hear rattling in the kitchen. Pots and pans moving. Beeps. Cutlery.

Ahh, peace.

âš¡

items.title: Eat Your Broccoli
items.summary: The funny thing about the future. Would you want to know…
items.content_html:
The funny thing about the future.

Would you want to know if you could?

What happens in a week. In a month. In a year.

In a decade.

In a life.

I was always thinking ahead (if not always planning for it), until some ess happened that made me focus on immediacy. On survival. On now.

I still hold onto that feeling daily (gratitude), but I also am planning ahead again (the long game).

So some balancing is in order.

Cherish the day; plan for tomorrow (and beyond).

Sure, it's obvious.

But I used to take todays for granted.

I used to take right now for granted.

It'll be here.Â 

It always has.

And so patience is a virtue, I hear.

Wait.Â 

Bide your time.

Patience, contrary to what others think, is not inaction.

It only looks that way.

And looks can be very, very, fake. I think that's the term.

You might know me as a vibe guy.

Just chilling.

But, really, the eyes-closed monk sitting indian-style floating a foot off the ground is just an act.

In reality, I'm starfaring.

Touching quasars and being propelled through the universe by broccoli farts.

In other words,

Thankful.

items.title: Malls In The Matrix
items.summary: Malls are changing. I would say dying, but I don't think…
items.content_html:
Malls are changing.

I would say dying, but I don't think they are.

They are changing.

Evolving.

Iterating.

I remember marveling at the amount of choices one had to shop in a mall.

I didn't realize how curated all these places actually were, how narrow the options, but it was cool to see way more than one store.

Now, malls are being repurposed.

Multi-use.Â 

I think it would be interesting if a company bought out an old mall and turned it into a business where their employees lived there as well. Like a campus.

Or a prison.

Of course, this isn't necessarily a happy idea, but some might be happy for it.

What I'm getting at here is what about the internet malls?

Right now, we are past the ooh and ahh stage of having a digital mall where we can shop at almost any store in the world.

There are too many choices, even though most of ours are still highly curated.

Will the internet shopping mall pass?

Or will it change?

Adapt.

Iterate.

I'm still waiting for ai to start suggesting a product ("link provided") whenever I ask it something even tangentially related.

That's part of this, I think. Ai shopping. Ai ads. Ai malls.

Ads on search browsers shifting to ads on ai prompts.

I know, I know.

But it's coming.

"This prompt answer brought to you by..."

Yuck.

It did turn Google into a monster. I wonder if it will do so for an ai company.

items.title: High Low There
items.summary: I had to write again. Can't start 2026 like an absurd…
items.content_html:
I had to write again.

Can't start 2026 like an absurd person would.

That was so 2025.

Listen, I got a question:

Do you have to get really low to get really high?

I mean to know what high truly means.

Do you have to be poor to appreciate being wealthy?

Do you have to have your heart broken to treasure and enjoy real love?

I mean, to value it as you should:

Priceless.Â 

If you were born rich, you tend to stay it, and take it for granted.

You wouldn't fully understand its literal value unless you lost it.

Same with love, I think, an always in love, never broken, heart. Seems like that kind of heart would break others' hearts.

You don't appreciate the unlimited power of love until it breaks you or someone close to you.

The more I wrestle with it, the more I am learning that our point of view, our perspective, might be one of the only truly unique things we have.

We all own a unique, one of one, perspective. A set of lenses through which we live.

And as similar as some people may appear, you'll find stark differences the further you zoom in.

So the challenge, then, should you choose to accept it is:

Learn from your singular perspective and the infinite of others.

Why do you (and they) see the world the way you (and they [this is the last time I will do the "and they" thing so just put it after every "you" following]) do?

How do you define wealth? Is it good or evil? And why?

How do you define love? Is it good or evil? Do you still believe in it? And why?

How do you define yourself? Are you good or evil? Do you still believe in you? And why?

And, perhaps most importantly, how do you define God? Is God benevolent or malevolent? Did you ever, or do you still, believe? And why?

items.title: MMXXVI
items.summary: Two Ms. Two Xs. A V and an I. That spells…
items.content_html:
Two Ms. Two Xs. A V and an I.

That spells Ememexexveeeeye.

Or something.

Rolls off the tongue, don't it?

Apparently, these are numerals but they look like capital letters if you ask me.

I am partial to LX, though.

60. And kinda, sorta, my name.

LX is the new XXIX (was going to say 30, but yeah), so I hear.

When in Rome...

Get ready, people.

Things will start out fast and hot.

I can feel it in my vibes.

May your Ememexexveeeeye be better than your Ememexexveee.

items.title: Party Horn
items.summary: Well, hey. Long time. What's it been, a year? Guffaw. I…
items.content_html:
Well, hey.

Long time.

What's it been, a year?

Guffaw.

I so funny.

Guffaws again.

Give me a second here.

Ok.

Man, I'm good.

So witty.

So this is my way of starting the new year on this here daily journal thing.

If you're new here, I ramble. Rant. Reason. Revere.

Mostly, this is my mental playground.Â 

Where I get to flip around and jump and flow my brain and finger muscles.

I'd love for you to join me.

Actually, I couldn't care less if you did, it just seems like people say that.

Ooooooooh, honorable reader, will you join my journey, please?

[Farts slowly, loudly, still going...you wonder "How does he do that?" The author, staring at you the whole time, never breaks eye contact. It is almost melodic. And ends on a high note, which, strangely, delights you. You got a few seconds before the smell hits. I would leave.]

Â

items.title: Ramble, Old Man, Ramble
items.summary: Only been writing again for the last couple of months, but…
items.content_html:
Only been writing again for the last couple of months, but it feels like a longer time.

I've been blessed (cursed?) with the ability to stop things I loved doing without missing it much.

I used to define myself by how much I could lift off my chest or over my head.

Always a spiritual sort, I prayed to heavy metal listening to heavy metal.

Found God there (and in a Muay Thai gym).

But I don't do it anymore.

Or at least for now I don't.

And I don't miss it (much).

You'd think I would, because it was a really big part of me, a big part of how I defined myself.

And that's how I kind of feel about writing.

I have written my entire life.

Have always loved the written word.

For a long time, I couldn't read or write anymore.

And that sucked. More than the not lifting thing. Which shocks me, writing that truth.

I started listening to stories and watching them.

And that helped, a lot, but it did not replace writing.

And so, all of that to just say, I'm very thankful to be able to type away again. To meander in my brain and pluck what I find and place it down on digital paper.

To ramble again, if no longer to rumble.

Rumbling is a young man's game.

Writing can be an old man's.

Something to look forward to (no old man here).

This might come across as sort of a down thing, but it's not.Â 

It's the exact opposite.

An up thing.

I'm writing again.

Wrote everyday here since early October.

I'm back, baby!

Or, at least, I am here.

I still get things off my chest, just now in a different form.

Lightweight, easy, easy.

What an interesting timeline.

To the last day of a good year.

Happy.
